exercises.name: Cat-Camel
exercises.description: A gentle spinal mobility exercise that alternates between arching and rounding the back while on all fours. Promotes flexibility and reduces stiffness in the lumbar and thoracic spine.
instructions: Start on all fours with hands directly under shoulders and knees under hips
Keep your neck neutral, looking at the floor
Inhale and slowly arch your back, dropping your belly toward the floor (Camel/Cow)
Lift your head and tailbone toward the ceiling
Exhale and round your spine toward the ceiling (Cat)
Tuck your chin and tailbone, drawing your belly button toward your spine
Move slowly and smoothly between positions
Hold each position for 2-3 seconds
common_mistakes: Not engaging the core during the movement
Hyperextending the neck when looking up
Keeping the hips stationary instead of tilting the pelvis
Holding breath instead of coordinating with movement

modifications.easier: Reduce range of motion, focus on mid-range
modifications.harder: Add a pause at each end position, slow the tempo

exercises.name: Cobra Stretch
exercises.description: A prone back extension exercise that gently stretches the abdominal muscles and strengthens the lower back extensors. Helps restore lumbar lordosis and relieve disc pressure.
instructions: Lie face down with legs extended and tops of feet on the floor
Place hands under shoulders, elbows close to body
Press into your hands and slowly lift your chest off the floor
Keep your hips and legs pressed into the mat
Extend only as far as comfortable, keeping elbows slightly bent
Hold the position, breathing normally
Slowly lower back to starting position
Keep shoulders away from ears throughout

modifications.easier: Sphinx pose - rest on forearms instead of hands
modifications.harder: Full cobra with arms straight, longer holds

exercises.name: Dead Bug
exercises.description: A supine core stability exercise that trains the deep stabilizers while moving the arms and legs. Teaches proper bracing and maintains neutral spine under load.
instructions: Lie on your back with arms extended toward ceiling
Lift legs to tabletop position (hips and knees at 90 degrees)
Press lower back firmly into the floor
Slowly extend one arm overhead and opposite leg toward floor
Keep your lower back pressed into the mat throughout
Return to starting position with control
Repeat on the opposite side
Exhale as you extend, inhale as you return
common_mistakes: Allowing lower back to arch off the floor
Moving too quickly and losing control
Not fully extending arm and leg
Holding breath instead of controlled breathing

modifications.easier: Move only legs, keep arms still, or reduce range of motion
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights, slow the tempo, hover leg lower

contraindications: Acute low back pain with flexion intolerance

exercises.name: Bodyweight Squat
exercises.description: A fundamental lower body exercise that strengthens the quadriceps, glutes, and core while improving mobility. Performed with bodyweight only, focusing on proper form and depth.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly turned out
Keep your chest up and core engaged
Initiate the movement by pushing your hips back
Bend your knees and lower your body as if sitting into a chair
Keep your knees tracking over your toes
Lower until thighs are parallel to the floor or as low as comfortable
Press through your heels to return to standing
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement
common_mistakes: Excessive forward lean of the torso
Knees drifting too far past toes
Rising onto toes instead of pressing through heels

modifications.easier: Use a chair for support, reduce depth
modifications.harder: Add pause at bottom, slow tempo, single leg progression

exercises.name: Standing Lumbar Flexion
exercises.description: A standing forward bend to assess lumbar flexion range of motion in a controlled, pain-free manner.
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart
Keep knees softly straight and arms relaxed
Slowly hinge forward, sliding hands toward your shins
Stop when you feel a gentle stretch
Return to standing with control
common_mistakes: Bending the knees into a squat

modifications.easier: Limit range to mid-shin or rest hands on thighs
modifications.harder: Hold the end position for 3-5 seconds

exercises.name: Standing Lumbar Extension
exercises.description: A gentle standing back bend used to assess lumbar extension and tolerance.
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart
Place hands on hips or lower back for support
Gently lean back, lifting the chest
Keep knees softly straight and avoid locking
Return to neutral standing position

modifications.easier: Reduce range of motion and keep gaze forward
modifications.harder: Hold the end position for 3-5 seconds

exercises.name: Standing Lumbar Side Bending
exercises.description: A standing side bend to assess lateral lumbar range of motion.
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart
Keep shoulders relaxed and arms at your sides
Slide one hand down the outside of your thigh
Keep hips stacked and avoid twisting
Return to standing with control
common_mistakes: Twisting the torso instead of bending sideways

modifications.easier: Reduce range of motion and keep both arms relaxed
modifications.harder: Hold the end position for 3-5 seconds

exercises.name: Bird Dog
exercises.description: A quadruped exercise that challenges core stability while extending opposite arm and leg. Strengthens the posterior chain and improves coordination.
instructions: Start on all fours with hands under shoulders, knees under hips
Keep spine neutral and core engaged
Slowly extend right arm forward and left leg back
Keep hips and shoulders level - don't rotate
Hold briefly at full extension
Return to starting position with control
Repeat on opposite side
Move slowly and deliberately
common_mistakes: Rotating hips or shoulders during movement
Arching lower back when extending leg
Lifting arm or leg too high

modifications.easier: Lift only arm or only leg, not both
modifications.harder: Add holds, draw squares with extended limbs

exercises.name: Side Plank
exercises.description: A lateral core stability exercise that strengthens the obliques and quadratus lumborum. Essential for spine stability in the frontal plane.
instructions: Lie on your side with elbow directly under shoulder
Stack feet or stagger them for stability
Lift hips off the ground, creating a straight line
Keep core engaged and hips lifted
Don't let hips sag or pike up
Hold for prescribed time
Lower with control and repeat on other side

modifications.easier: Bend bottom knee and rest on floor
modifications.harder: Lift top leg, add hip dips

exercises.name: Pelvic Tilt
exercises.description: A fundamental exercise that teaches awareness and control of pelvic position. Gently mobilizes the lumbar spine and activates deep core muscles.
instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on floor
Place arms at your sides, palms down
Gently flatten your lower back against the floor
Tilt your pelvis up slightly, engaging your lower abs
Hold for 2-3 seconds
Release and let your back return to neutral
Repeat slowly and with control

modifications.easier: Place hands under lower back to feel the movement
modifications.harder: Progress to supine marching while maintaining tilt

exercises.name: Single Knee to Chest
exercises.description: A gentle stretch that flexes the lumbar spine and stretches the gluteal muscles. Relieves tension in the lower back.
instructions: Lie on your back with both knees bent
Bring one knee toward your chest
Grasp behind the thigh or on top of the shin
Gently pull the knee closer until you feel a stretch
Keep opposite leg bent or extended based on comfort
Hold the stretch, breathing normally
Release and repeat on other side
common_mistakes: Pulling on the kneecap instead of thigh

modifications.easier: Use a towel around thigh if can't reach
modifications.harder: Double knee to chest for deeper stretch

exercises.name: Double Knee to Chest
exercises.description: A deeper lumbar flexion stretch that brings both knees toward the chest simultaneously. Provides a gentle stretch to the entire lower back.
instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent
Bring both knees toward your chest
Wrap arms around your shins or behind thighs
Gently pull knees closer to deepen stretch
Keep your head and shoulders relaxed on the floor
Hold and breathe deeply
Release slowly back to starting position

modifications.easier: Keep one foot on floor, pull one knee at a time
modifications.harder: Add gentle rocking side to side

exercises.name: Supine Spinal Twist
exercises.description: A rotational stretch performed lying down that increases thoracic and lumbar mobility. Stretches the paraspinal muscles and external obliques.
instructions: Lie on your back with arms extended to sides
Bend both knees and lift feet off floor
Slowly lower both knees to one side
Keep shoulders pressed into the floor
Turn head to opposite direction if comfortable
Hold and breathe into the stretch
Return to center and repeat on other side
common_mistakes: Letting opposite shoulder lift off floor

modifications.easier: Keep feet on floor and just drop knees to side
modifications.harder: Straighten top leg for deeper stretch

exercises.name: Child's Pose
exercises.description: A restorative position that gently stretches the lower back, hips, and thighs. Excellent for relaxation and relieving tension.
instructions: Start on hands and knees
Sit hips back toward heels
Extend arms forward on the floor
Rest forehead on the mat
Let your entire body relax
Breathe deeply into your lower back
Hold for prescribed duration

modifications.easier: Place pillow between thighs and calves
modifications.harder: Walk hands to each side for lateral stretch

exercises.name: Prone Press-Up (McKenzie)
exercises.description: A McKenzie method exercise that promotes lumbar extension. Helps centralize disc material and restore normal lordosis.
instructions: Lie face down with hands under shoulders
Keep hips and legs completely relaxed on floor
Press through hands to lift upper body
Keep pelvis on the floor throughout
Extend as far as comfortable
Lower back down with control
Repeat in a rhythmic fashion

modifications.harder: Hold at top for longer, add sag

exercises.name: Glute Bridge
exercises.description: A fundamental hip extension exercise that strengthens the gluteal muscles and teaches hip hinge mechanics. Supports lumbar stability.
instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat
Place feet hip-width apart, arms at sides
Press through heels to lift hips toward ceiling
Squeeze glutes at the top
Create a straight line from shoulders to knees
Hold briefly at top
Lower with control
Keep core engaged throughout
common_mistakes: Pushing through toes instead of heels

modifications.harder: Single leg bridge, add marching

exercises.name: Single Leg Glute Bridge
exercises.description: An advanced bridge variation that isolates one glute at a time. Addresses asymmetries and builds unilateral strength.
instructions: Lie on back with knees bent
Extend one leg straight or hold knee to chest
Press through heel of planted foot
Lift hips keeping pelvis level
Squeeze glute at top
Lower with control
Complete all reps before switching sides
common_mistakes: Letting hips drop to one side

modifications.easier: Keep lifted leg bent with foot hovering
modifications.harder: Add hold at top, resistance band

exercises.name: Clamshell
exercises.description: A side-lying hip strengthening exercise targeting the gluteus medius. Essential for hip stability and preventing knee valgus.
instructions: Lie on your side with hips and knees bent 45 degrees
Stack hips and shoulders, keep feet together
Lift top knee while keeping feet together
Don't let pelvis rotate backward
Hold briefly at top
Lower with control
Complete all reps before switching sides

modifications.harder: Add resistance band around thighs

exercises.name: Side-Lying Leg Lift
exercises.description: A simple hip abduction exercise performed lying on your side. Strengthens the gluteus medius and tensor fasciae latae.
instructions: Lie on your side with body in straight line
Support head with bottom arm
Keep top leg straight
Lift top leg toward ceiling
Keep toes pointing forward, not up
Lower with control
Don't let leg swing forward or back
common_mistakes: Lifting too high and tilting pelvis

modifications.harder: Add ankle weight or resistance band

exercises.name: Prone Hip Extension
exercises.description: A prone exercise that isolates the gluteus maximus. Teaches proper hip extension without lumbar compensation.
instructions: Lie face down with arms under forehead
Keep legs straight and together
Squeeze glute and lift one leg off floor
Keep knee straight throughout
Don't rotate hip or arch lower back excessively
Lower with control
Alternate legs or complete all reps on one side
common_mistakes: Arching lower back to lift higher

modifications.harder: Add ankle weight, hold at top

exercises.name: Quadruped Hip Extension
exercises.description: An all-fours exercise targeting the glutes through hip extension. Also known as donkey kicks.
instructions: Start on hands and knees
Keep spine neutral and core engaged
Lift one leg behind you, keeping knee bent
Push heel toward ceiling
Keep hips level - don't rotate
Lower with control
Complete all reps before switching

modifications.harder: Add ankle weight, resistance band

exercises.name: Fire Hydrant
exercises.description: A quadruped hip abduction exercise that targets the gluteus medius and external rotators. Improves hip stability.
instructions: Start on hands and knees
Keep spine neutral and core engaged
Lift one knee out to the side
Keep knee bent at 90 degrees
Don't shift weight to opposite side
Lower with control
Keep hips level throughout
common_mistakes: Shifting weight away from lifting leg

modifications.harder: Add ankle weight, circles at top

exercises.name: Supine Marching
exercises.description: A core stability exercise that challenges the ability to maintain neutral spine while moving the legs. Precursor to dead bug.
instructions: Lie on back with knees bent, feet flat
Find neutral spine and engage core
Slowly lift one foot off floor (march)
Keep pelvis stable - no rocking
Lower foot with control
Alternate sides in marching pattern
Maintain steady breathing
common_mistakes: Allowing pelvis to rock side to side

modifications.harder: Lift to tabletop, progress to dead bug

exercises.name: Heel Slides
exercises.description: A gentle core exercise that teaches spinal stability during leg movement. Often one of the first exercises post-injury.
instructions: Lie on back with knees bent
Find neutral spine position
Engage core gently
Slowly slide one heel away from body
Extend leg as far as you can maintain neutral spine
Slide back to starting position
Alternate legs
common_mistakes: Letting back arch as leg extends
Extending too far and losing form

modifications.harder: Progress to supine marching or dead bug

exercises.name: Abdominal Bracing
exercises.description: A foundational core activation technique that engages the transverse abdominis and multifidus. The basis for all other core exercises.
instructions: Lie on back with knees bent
Place fingers on belly just inside hip bones
Gently draw belly button toward spine
Feel muscles tighten under fingers
Don't hold breath - breathe normally
Don't flatten or tuck pelvis
Hold the gentle contraction
common_mistakes: Using rectus abdominis instead of deep muscles

modifications.easier: Practice with cough to feel the muscles
modifications.harder: Maintain brace during arm/leg movements

exercises.name: Drawing-In Maneuver
exercises.description: A core activation technique focusing on the transverse abdominis. Teaches isolated activation of the deepest core muscle.
instructions: Lie on back with knees bent
Relax your abdominal muscles completely
Slowly draw belly button down toward spine
Imagine pulling navel toward the floor
Keep breathing normally
Don't move pelvis or flatten back
Hold the subtle contraction

modifications.harder: Maintain during functional movements

exercises.name: Front Plank
exercises.description: A foundational isometric core exercise that strengthens the entire anterior chain. Teaches global core stability.
instructions: Start in push-up position or on forearms
Keep body in straight line from head to heels
Engage core and squeeze glutes
Don't let hips sag or pike up
Keep neck neutral, looking at floor
Breathe steadily throughout
Hold for prescribed duration

modifications.easier: Drop to knees, or elevate hands on surface
modifications.harder: Add arm/leg lifts, shoulder taps

exercises.name: Modified Plank (Knees Down)
exercises.description: A regression of the standard plank performed with knees on the ground. Reduces load while building core endurance.
instructions: Start on forearms with knees on ground
Walk knees back until body is in line
Keep straight line from head to knees
Engage core and don't let hips sag
Keep shoulders over elbows
Breathe normally throughout
Hold for prescribed duration
common_mistakes: Hips too high or too low

modifications.harder: Progress to full plank

exercises.name: Piriformis Stretch
exercises.description: A stretch targeting the piriformis muscle deep in the buttock. Can help relieve sciatic symptoms caused by piriformis tightness.
instructions: Lie on back with both knees bent
Cross one ankle over opposite knee
Thread hands behind the bottom thigh
Pull bottom leg toward chest
Keep crossed knee pressing away
Feel stretch deep in buttock
Hold and breathe, then switch sides

modifications.easier: Keep bottom foot on floor, press knee away
modifications.harder: Use hands on knee to deepen rotation

exercises.name: Figure Four Stretch
exercises.description: Another name for the supine piriformis stretch, creating a figure-4 shape with the legs. Stretches hip external rotators.
instructions: Lie on back with knees bent
Place right ankle on left thigh above knee
Let right knee fall open
Lift left foot off floor
Pull left thigh toward chest
Keep lower back on floor
Hold and breathe
common_mistakes: Not letting knee fall open enough

modifications.harder: Straighten bottom leg

exercises.name: Kneeling Hip Flexor Stretch
exercises.description: A lunge-position stretch targeting the iliopsoas and rectus femoris. Essential for those who sit for long periods.
instructions: Kneel on one knee with other foot forward
Keep front knee over ankle
Tuck pelvis under (posterior tilt)
Shift weight forward until stretch is felt
Keep torso upright
Don't arch lower back
Hold and switch sides
common_mistakes: Arching lower back instead of tucking pelvis

modifications.easier: Use chair or wall for balance
modifications.harder: Add overhead reach, side bend

exercises.name: Standing Hip Flexor Stretch
exercises.description: A standing variation of the hip flexor stretch. Good alternative if kneeling is uncomfortable.
instructions: Stand in split stance, back leg straight
Tuck pelvis under (flatten lower back)
Keep torso upright
Squeeze back glute
Shift weight forward slightly
Feel stretch in front of back hip
Hold and switch sides

modifications.easier: Hold wall or chair for balance
modifications.harder: Add arm raise overhead

exercises.name: Supine Hamstring Stretch
exercises.description: A gentle hamstring stretch performed lying down. Allows for controlled stretching without putting stress on the lower back.
instructions: Lie on back with both legs extended
Lift one leg toward ceiling
Keep knee as straight as comfortable
Hold behind thigh or calf
Keep opposite leg flat on floor
Don't let lower back arch
Hold and breathe

modifications.easier: Use strap or towel around foot
modifications.harder: Pull leg closer, add ankle flexion

exercises.name: Doorway Hamstring Stretch
exercises.description: A supported hamstring stretch using a doorframe. Allows for passive stretching with excellent control.
instructions: Lie on back in doorway
Place one leg up the door frame
Keep other leg through the doorway, flat on floor
Scoot closer to increase stretch
Keep stretching leg straight
Relax and breathe
Hold then switch sides

modifications.harder: Scoot closer, add ankle pumps

exercises.name: Seated Forward Fold
exercises.description: A seated stretch targeting the hamstrings and lower back. Also stretches the entire posterior chain.
instructions: Sit with legs extended in front
Sit tall, lengthening spine
Hinge forward from hips
Reach toward feet (or shins)
Keep back as flat as possible
Don't round excessively
Hold and breathe

modifications.harder: Work toward deeper fold over time

exercises.name: Standing Back Extension
exercises.description: A standing lumbar extension exercise. Can be done anywhere and is good for those who've been sitting.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Place hands on lower back
Gently lean backward
Support lower back with hands
Extend only as far as comfortable
Keep knees straight
Return to upright slowly

modifications.harder: Reach arms overhead while extending

exercises.name: Sphinx Pose
exercises.description: A gentle prone extension position resting on forearms. Promotes lumbar lordosis with less intensity than cobra.
instructions: Lie face down with legs extended
Place forearms on floor, elbows under shoulders
Press forearms down and lift chest
Keep hips on the floor
Relax shoulders away from ears
Look forward, neck neutral
Hold and breathe

modifications.easier: Rest on elbows with less lift
modifications.harder: Progress to cobra/press-up

exercises.name: Lumbar Rotation Stretch
exercises.description: A seated or lying rotation stretch for the lumbar spine. Improves rotational mobility and stretches the obliques.
instructions: Sit in chair or on floor
Keep hips facing forward
Slowly rotate torso to one side
Use hand on opposite knee for leverage
Keep shoulders level
Hold at end range
Return to center and repeat other side

modifications.harder: Add a slight side bend at end range

exercises.name: Seated Figure Four Stretch
exercises.description: A seated version of the figure-4 stretch. Can be done at a desk or anywhere you can sit.
instructions: Sit tall in a sturdy chair
Place one ankle on opposite knee
Let crossed knee fall open
Keep sitting bones evenly weighted
Hinge forward slightly from hips
Feel stretch in outer hip/buttock
Hold and switch sides

modifications.harder: Lean forward more, press knee down

exercises.name: Wall Sit
exercises.description: An isometric leg exercise performed against a wall. Builds quadriceps strength and endurance while maintaining neutral spine.
instructions: Stand with back against wall
Walk feet out about 2 feet
Slide down until thighs are parallel to floor
Keep knees over ankles
Press lower back into wall
Arms at sides or crossed
Hold for prescribed time
common_mistakes: Lower back arching away from wall

modifications.harder: Single leg, add holds

exercises.name: Wall Angels
exercises.description: A wall exercise that improves thoracic extension and shoulder mobility. Helps counteract forward head posture.
instructions: Stand with back against wall
Feet about 6 inches from wall
Press lower back and head into wall
Place arms against wall in goalpost position
Slide arms up overhead keeping contact with wall
Slide back down to goalpost
Move slowly and with control

modifications.harder: Slow tempo, pause at top

exercises.name: Thoracic Extension on Foam Roller
exercises.description: A foam roller exercise targeting thoracic spine extension. Helps improve upper back mobility and posture.
instructions: Lie on foam roller placed horizontally under upper back
Support head with hands interlaced behind neck
Keep knees bent, feet flat on floor
Extend backward over the roller
Don't let lower back arch excessively
Roll to different segments of thoracic spine
Spend extra time on stiff areas

modifications.harder: Add arms overhead

exercises.name: Quadruped Thoracic Rotation
exercises.description: A rotation exercise performed on all fours. Isolates thoracic rotation while stabilizing the lumbar spine.
instructions: Start on hands and knees
Place one hand behind head
Rotate that elbow toward opposite arm
Then rotate up toward ceiling
Keep hips and lower back still
Follow elbow with eyes
Return and repeat, then switch sides
common_mistakes: Rotating from hips instead of thoracic

modifications.harder: Thread the needle variation

exercises.name: Thread the Needle
exercises.description: A rotation stretch combining thoracic mobility with a shoulder stretch. Opens up the mid-back and shoulders.
instructions: Start on hands and knees
Reach one arm under your body
Thread it through to the opposite side
Lower shoulder and head to floor
Keep hips over knees
Feel stretch through mid-back and shoulder
Hold, then switch sides

modifications.harder: Reach overhead arm up to ceiling

exercises.name: Seated Cat-Cow
exercises.description: A seated version of the cat-cow exercise. Can be done at a desk or anywhere seating is available.
instructions: Sit tall at edge of chair
Place hands on knees
Inhale and arch back, lift chest (cow)
Look slightly upward
Exhale and round spine, tuck chin (cat)
Draw belly button back
Move smoothly between positions
common_mistakes: Only moving neck, not whole spine

modifications.harder: Add holds at each end position

exercises.name: Prone Swimming
exercises.description: A prone exercise alternating arm and leg lifts like swimming. Strengthens the entire posterior chain.
instructions: Lie face down with arms extended overhead
Lift right arm and left leg simultaneously
Keep movement controlled and small
Lower and lift opposite arm and leg
Continue alternating in swimming motion
Keep head neutral, looking down
Breathe normally throughout

modifications.easier: Lift only arms or only legs
modifications.harder: Faster tempo, longer duration

exercises.name: Supine Leg Lowering
exercises.description: A core challenge lowering legs from vertical while maintaining neutral spine. Tests and builds core control.
instructions: Lie on back with legs vertical, pointing to ceiling
Press lower back firmly into floor
Slowly lower both legs toward floor
Stop when lower back starts to arch
Return legs to vertical
Only go as low as you can maintain flat back
common_mistakes: Lowering too far and arching back

modifications.harder: Lower further, slow tempo

exercises.name: Bicycle Crunch
exercises.description: A dynamic core exercise targeting the obliques through rotation. Also works rectus abdominis.
instructions: Lie on back with hands behind head
Lift shoulders off floor
Bring knees to tabletop position
Rotate and bring elbow toward opposite knee
Extend other leg out straight
Switch sides in cycling motion
Keep lower back pressed down

modifications.easier: Keep both feet on floor, just rotate upper body
modifications.harder: Slow tempo, lower extended leg

exercises.name: Standing Hip Circles
exercises.description: A dynamic hip mobility exercise performed standing. Warms up the hip joints through full range of motion.
instructions: Stand on one leg, hold wall for balance
Lift other knee up in front
Circle the leg out to the side
Continue circle behind you
Bring back to front to complete circle
Do prescribed reps then reverse direction
Switch legs
common_mistakes: Moving from torso instead of hip

modifications.harder: Larger circles, no support

exercises.name: 90-90 Hip Stretch
exercises.description: A seated hip stretch with both legs at 90 degrees. Targets hip internal and external rotation simultaneously.
instructions: Sit on floor with one leg in front, one behind
Both knees bent at 90 degrees
Front shin parallel to your torso
Back leg behind you, shin parallel to side
Sit tall and square your hips
Lean forward over front leg for more stretch
Hold then switch sides

modifications.easier: Sit on yoga block, reduce angles
modifications.harder: Lean forward more, longer holds

exercises.name: Happy Baby Pose
exercises.description: A restorative yoga pose that stretches the inner thighs, groin, and lower back. Very relaxing.
instructions: Lie on back and bring knees toward chest
Grab outside edges of feet
Open knees wider than torso
Pull feet toward floor beside ribs
Keep lower back on floor
Rock gently side to side if desired
Relax and breathe deeply

modifications.easier: Hold behind knees instead of feet
modifications.harder: Straighten legs partially

exercises.name: Sciatic Nerve Glide
exercises.description: A neural mobilization technique for the sciatic nerve. Helps reduce nerve sensitivity and improve mobility.
instructions: Sit at edge of chair
Straighten one leg with foot flexed
Simultaneously look up/extend neck
Then bend knee and point toes
Simultaneously look down/flex neck
Create a gentle pumping motion
Move smoothly, never force

modifications.harder: Slow the movement down more

exercises.name: Femoral Nerve Glide
exercises.description: A neural mobilization for the femoral nerve. Helpful for front of thigh symptoms.
instructions: Stand holding wall for balance
Bend knee and hold ankle behind you
Tuck pelvis under (posterior tilt)
Gently pull heel toward buttock
Simultaneously extend or flex neck
Create gentle oscillating motion
Never force into pain

modifications.harder: Add hip extension

exercises.name: QL Stretch (Side-Lying)
exercises.description: A stretch targeting the quadratus lumborum muscle. Helps relieve lateral low back tightness.
instructions: Lie on your side on the edge of bed/table
Let top leg hang off the edge
Reach top arm overhead
Let gravity create the stretch
Feel stretch along side of lower back
Breathe into the stretch
Hold then switch sides

modifications.easier: Side bend in standing with arm overhead
modifications.harder: Add slight rotation

exercises.name: Quad Sets (Isometric)
exercises.description: An isometric quadriceps contraction performed with the knee extended. Fundamental exercise for early knee rehabilitation that activates the VMO and prevents quadriceps atrophy.
instructions: Lie on your back or sit with leg extended
Place a small rolled towel under your knee for support
Tighten your thigh muscle by pushing the back of your knee down
Try to lift your heel slightly off the surface
Hold the contraction for 5-10 seconds
You should see your kneecap move upward
Relax and repeat

modifications.easier: Shorter hold times, focus on muscle activation
modifications.harder: Longer holds, add ankle weights, combine with SLR

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise (Supine)
exercises.description: A fundamental knee rehabilitation exercise that strengthens the quadriceps without bending the knee. Essential after knee surgery or injury to maintain muscle mass.
instructions: Lie on your back with one leg bent, foot flat on floor
Keep the other leg straight with toes pointing up
Perform a quad set first to lock out the knee
Slowly raise the straight leg to height of bent knee
Hold briefly at the top
Lower slowly with control
Keep the knee fully extended throughout
common_mistakes: Allowing knee to bend during lift
Lifting too high and arching back
Not performing quad set before lifting

modifications.easier: Reduce height of lift, use quad set only
modifications.harder: Add ankle weight, slow the tempo, hold at top

contraindications: Severe low back pain with hip flexion

exercises.name: Short Arc Quadriceps
exercises.description: An exercise targeting the last 30 degrees of knee extension where the quadriceps are most challenged. Critical for regaining terminal knee extension strength.
instructions: Lie on your back with a bolster or rolled towel under your knee
The bolster should create about 30 degrees of knee bend
Slowly straighten your knee, lifting your foot
Focus on fully extending the knee
Hold at full extension for 2-3 seconds
Lower slowly back to the bolster
Keep thigh on the bolster throughout
common_mistakes: Bolster too large or too small

modifications.harder: Add ankle weight, longer holds

exercises.name: Terminal Knee Extension (TKE)
exercises.description: A standing exercise using resistance band to strengthen the quadriceps through the final degrees of knee extension. Excellent for VMO activation and patellar tracking.
instructions: Attach resistance band to sturdy anchor at knee height
Loop band behind your knee, facing the anchor
Stand with slight bend in the banded knee
Straighten the knee against the band resistance
Squeeze your quadriceps at full extension
Hold for 2-3 seconds
Slowly allow knee to bend slightly and repeat

modifications.harder: Heavier band, single leg stance, longer holds

exercises.name: Wall Squat Hold
exercises.description: An isometric squat performed against a wall that builds quadriceps endurance while maintaining proper knee alignment. Good for patellofemoral rehabilitation.
instructions: Stand with back against wall, feet shoulder-width apart
Walk feet out about 18 inches from wall
Slide down until thighs are parallel to floor (or less)
Keep knees aligned over ankles, not past toes
Press lower back into wall
Hold position for prescribed time
Slide back up to standing
common_mistakes: Not going low enough for challenge

modifications.harder: Lower position, single leg, ball squeeze between knees

exercises.name: Forward Step-Up
exercises.description: A functional strengthening exercise that mimics stair climbing. Builds quadriceps and glute strength while improving single-leg stability.
instructions: Stand facing a step or sturdy platform
Place entire foot of working leg on step
Press through heel to step up onto platform
Bring trailing leg up to meet the other
Step back down with control, leading with same leg
Keep knee aligned over toes throughout
Complete all reps on one side before switching
common_mistakes: Knee caving inward on working leg
Step too high for current strength
Not fully extending hip at top

modifications.easier: Lower step height, use rail for balance
modifications.harder: Higher step, add weights, slower tempo

contraindications: Acute knee pain with stair climbing

exercises.name: Lateral Step-Up
exercises.description: A step-up variation performed from the side that emphasizes lateral hip stability and addresses frontal plane knee control. Important for preventing knee valgus.
instructions: Stand beside a step with working leg closest to platform
Place entire foot on step, toes pointing forward
Press through heel and step up, bringing other leg to meet
Keep pelvis level throughout the movement
Step down with control to starting position
Focus on knee tracking over second toe
Complete all reps before switching sides

modifications.easier: Lower step, touch down on top instead of full step-up
modifications.harder: Higher step, add weights, pause at top

exercises.name: Forward Step-Down
exercises.description: An eccentric quadriceps exercise performed by lowering from a step. Emphasizes control during the lowering phase which is critical for stair descent and deceleration.
instructions: Stand on step with toes near edge
Shift weight to stance leg
Slowly lower opposite foot toward floor
Bend stance knee with control
Lightly tap heel to floor (or hover)
Push through stance leg to return to start
Focus on slow, controlled descent

modifications.easier: Lower step, hold rail, dont go as deep
modifications.harder: Higher step, add weight, slower tempo

exercises.name: Mini Squats
exercises.description: A partial squat performed through a limited range of motion. Safe way to begin loading the knee after injury while maintaining proper mechanics.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Hold onto chair or counter for balance if needed
Slowly bend knees to about 30-45 degrees
Keep weight in heels, chest up
Knees should track over toes
Push through heels to return to standing
Squeeze glutes at the top

modifications.harder: Deeper squat, add resistance band, single leg

exercises.name: Goblet Squat
exercises.description: A squat variation holding weight at chest level that promotes upright torso position and proper squat mechanics. The counterbalance helps achieve better depth.
instructions: Hold weight (dumbbell or kettlebell) at chest
Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder-width
Toes pointed slightly outward
Push hips back and bend knees to lower
Keep chest up and weight close to body
Lower until thighs are parallel to floor
Drive through heels to stand

modifications.harder: Heavier weight, pause at bottom, tempo squats

exercises.name: Prone Hamstring Curl
exercises.description: An isolation exercise for the hamstrings performed lying face down. Builds hamstring strength important for knee stability and ACL protection.
instructions: Lie face down on mat or bench
Keep hips pressed into surface
Slowly bend knee, bringing heel toward buttock
Pause at top of movement
Lower slowly with control
Avoid lifting hip off the surface
Keep movement smooth and controlled

modifications.harder: Add ankle weight or resistance band

exercises.name: Standing Hamstring Curl
exercises.description: A functional hamstring exercise performed standing that also challenges balance. Can be done with or without resistance.
instructions: Stand holding onto chair or wall for balance
Shift weight to stance leg
Slowly bend working knee, bringing heel toward buttock
Keep thighs parallel to each other
Pause at top of movement
Lower slowly with control
Avoid leaning trunk forward

modifications.harder: Add ankle weight, no support, resistance band

exercises.name: Slider Hamstring Curl
exercises.description: A challenging hamstring exercise using sliders or a towel on a smooth floor. Works the hamstrings through hip extension and knee flexion simultaneously.
instructions: Lie on back with heels on sliders (or towel on hard floor)
Lift hips into bridge position
Slowly slide heels away from body
Extend legs while keeping hips lifted
Slide heels back toward buttocks
Maintain hip height throughout
Focus on hamstring contraction

modifications.easier: Lower hips between reps, shorter range
modifications.harder: Single leg, slower tempo, hold at extended position

exercises.name: Nordic Hamstring Curl
exercises.description: An advanced eccentric hamstring exercise proven to reduce hamstring injury risk. Emphasizes the lengthening phase of hamstring contraction.
instructions: Kneel on padded surface with ankles secured
Partner holds ankles or use anchor
Keep body straight from knees to head
Slowly lower torso toward ground
Control descent as long as possible
Catch yourself with hands when needed
Push back up to kneeling and repeat

modifications.easier: Use resistance band for assistance, limit range
modifications.harder: Slower descent, hands-free return, weighted

exercises.name: Romanian Deadlift (RDL)
exercises.description: A hip-hinge exercise that lengthens the hamstrings under load. Builds posterior chain strength and teaches proper hip mechanics.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, knees slightly bent
Hold weights in front of thighs
Push hips back while keeping spine neutral
Lower weights along legs toward floor
Feel stretch in hamstrings
Stop when you feel mild stretch (not pain)
Drive hips forward to return to standing

modifications.easier: Bodyweight only, limit range, hand on wall
modifications.harder: Heavier weight, single leg RDL

exercises.name: Single Leg Romanian Deadlift
exercises.description: An advanced unilateral hip hinge that challenges balance while strengthening the hamstrings and glutes. Addresses asymmetries and builds stability.
instructions: Stand on one leg with slight knee bend
Hold weight in opposite hand (or both hands)
Hinge at hip, extending free leg behind
Keep hips square to the ground
Lower until torso is nearly parallel to floor
Drive through heel to return to standing
Maintain balance throughout

modifications.easier: Touch wall or chair, kickstand stance, limit range
modifications.harder: Heavier weight, eyes closed, unstable surface

exercises.name: Lateral Band Walk
exercises.description: A resistance band exercise targeting the gluteus medius to improve hip stability and prevent knee valgus. Essential for patellofemoral and ACL rehabilitation.
instructions: Place resistance band around ankles (or above knees)
Stand with feet hip-width apart, knees slightly bent
Maintain slight squat position throughout
Step sideways, leading with one foot
Follow with other foot, maintaining tension
Keep toes pointing forward
Take 10 steps one direction, then reverse
common_mistakes: Standing too upright (not in mini squat)
Losing tension in band between steps

modifications.harder: Heavier band, deeper squat, band at ankles

exercises.name: Monster Walk
exercises.description: A diagonal walking pattern with resistance band that targets both hip abductors and external rotators. Builds hip strength for knee stability.
instructions: Place resistance band around ankles
Stand in quarter squat position
Step forward and outward at 45-degree angle
Follow with other leg in same pattern
Maintain band tension throughout
Keep knees over toes
Walk forward then backward
common_mistakes: Steps too small to challenge muscles

modifications.harder: Heavier band, deeper squat, larger steps

exercises.name: Hip Hike
exercises.description: A standing exercise targeting the gluteus medius that teaches pelvis control. Important for preventing Trendelenburg gait and knee valgus.
instructions: Stand on step with one foot, other hanging off edge
Hold rail or wall for balance
Let hanging hip drop below stance hip level
Use hip muscles to hike pelvis up on hanging side
Lift until pelvis is level or slightly higher
Lower slowly with control
Keep stance knee straight but not locked
common_mistakes: Not dropping hip enough at start

modifications.harder: Higher step, add ankle weight on hanging leg

exercises.name: Single Leg Stance
exercises.description: A fundamental balance exercise that activates hip stabilizers and improves proprioception. Foundation for all single-leg activities.
instructions: Stand near wall or chair for safety
Shift weight to one leg
Lift other foot slightly off ground
Keep stance knee slightly bent, not locked
Maintain level pelvis
Focus on a fixed point for balance
Hold for prescribed time, then switch
common_mistakes: Letting hip drop on lifted side

modifications.harder: Eyes closed, unstable surface, arm movements

exercises.name: Single Leg Squat
exercises.description: An advanced single-leg exercise that tests and builds quadriceps, hip, and core strength. Also assesses knee valgus tendency and movement quality.
instructions: Stand on one leg with arms extended forward
Extend other leg in front of you
Slowly bend stance knee to lower body
Keep knee tracking over second toe
Lower as far as you can with good form
Push through heel to return to standing
Maintain upright trunk throughout

modifications.easier: Hold TRX or rail, squat to box
modifications.harder: Deeper range, arms overhead, on unstable surface

exercises.name: Split Squat
exercises.description: A stationary lunge position that builds unilateral leg strength. More stable than lunges while still addressing side-to-side strength differences.
instructions: Stand in staggered stance, front foot flat
Back foot on toes, heel lifted
Lower straight down by bending both knees
Front knee stays over ankle
Back knee lowers toward floor
Push through front heel to rise
Keep torso upright throughout

modifications.harder: Add dumbbells, elevate rear foot (Bulgarian)

exercises.name: Bulgarian Split Squat
exercises.description: An elevated split squat with rear foot on bench that increases range of motion and challenge. Excellent for addressing leg strength asymmetries.
instructions: Stand facing away from bench or step
Place top of rear foot on elevated surface
Hop front foot forward to comfortable distance
Lower by bending front knee
Keep front knee over ankle
Lower until front thigh is parallel to floor
Drive through front heel to rise
common_mistakes: Front foot too close to bench
Rising onto toes of front foot
Back foot too far inside or outside

modifications.harder: Add dumbbells, pause at bottom, deficit

exercises.name: Heel Slides for Knee Flexion
exercises.description: A gentle range of motion exercise to improve knee flexion after surgery or injury. One of the first exercises prescribed post-operatively.
instructions: Lie on back with legs extended
Slowly slide heel toward buttock
Bend knee as far as comfortable
Use strap around foot for assistance if needed
Hold at end range briefly
Slide heel back to starting position
Move slowly and smoothly

modifications.harder: Add overpressure with strap at end range

exercises.name: Prone Knee Flexion Stretch
exercises.description: A gravity-assisted knee flexion exercise performed face down. Allows the weight of the leg to assist in achieving knee bend.
instructions: Lie face down on bed with knee at edge
Let lower leg hang off edge of bed
Allow gravity to bend the knee
Use other foot to gently push for more bend
Hold at comfortable stretch
Slowly straighten and repeat
Support thigh on bed throughout

modifications.harder: Use strap for sustained stretch

exercises.name: Seated Knee Extension Stretch
exercises.description: A stretch to achieve full knee extension, critical after knee surgery. Loss of extension affects gait and increases joint stress.
instructions: Sit in chair with leg extended on another chair
Place heel on edge of second chair
Let knee sag toward floor with gravity
Can place light weight on thigh for stretch
Hold for sustained stretch
Focus on relaxing quadriceps
Breathe normally throughout

modifications.easier: No added weight, rolled towel under ankle
modifications.harder: Small weight on thigh, longer duration

exercises.name: Prone Knee Extension (Hang)
exercises.description: A prone position stretch using gravity to achieve terminal knee extension. Helpful for restoring the last degrees of extension.
instructions: Lie face down on bed or table
Position knee at edge with kneecap just over edge
Let lower leg hang, gravity pulls knee straight
Can add ankle weight for more stretch
Hold for sustained duration
Relax and let gravity work
Breathe normally

modifications.harder: Add ankle weight, longer duration

exercises.name: Stationary Bike for ROM
exercises.description: Using a stationary bike to improve knee range of motion. The circular motion promotes flexion and extension through functional movement.
instructions: Adjust seat height - start higher for limited ROM
Begin with gentle rocking back and forth
Progress to partial rotations as able
Work toward full revolutions
Keep resistance low initially
Pedal in both directions
Duration matters more than intensity
common_mistakes: Not warming up with rocking first

modifications.harder: Lower seat, add light resistance

exercises.name: Patellar Mobilization
exercises.description: Manual mobilization of the kneecap to maintain or restore patellar mobility. Important after knee surgery or immobilization.
instructions: Sit or lie with leg extended and relaxed
Place fingers on edges of kneecap
Gently push patella side to side
Then push up and down
Move slowly and within comfort
Spend extra time on restricted directions
Keep quadriceps completely relaxed
common_mistakes: Pressing on patella instead of edges

modifications.harder: Longer holds at end range of each direction

exercises.name: Standing Quadriceps Stretch
exercises.description: A classic stretch for the quadriceps and hip flexors performed standing. Improves knee flexion range and reduces anterior knee tension.
instructions: Stand on one leg, hold wall for balance
Bend other knee and grasp ankle behind you
Pull heel toward buttock
Keep knees together
Tuck pelvis under (posterior tilt)
Feel stretch in front of thigh
Hold and breathe, then switch sides
common_mistakes: Knee drifting forward of stance leg

modifications.easier: Use strap if cannot reach ankle
modifications.harder: Add hip extension, no support

exercises.name: Prone Quadriceps Stretch
exercises.description: A quadriceps stretch performed lying face down that provides a stable position for those with balance limitations.
instructions: Lie face down on mat
Bend one knee and reach back to grasp ankle
Gently pull heel toward buttock
Keep hips pressed into floor
Feel stretch in front of thigh
Hold and breathe normally
Release and switch sides

modifications.harder: Lift thigh slightly off floor

exercises.name: Kneeling Quadriceps Stretch
exercises.description: An intense quadriceps and hip flexor stretch performed in a half-kneeling position with rear foot elevated.
instructions: Kneel in half-kneeling position near wall or couch
Place back foot up on wall/couch behind you
Scoot back knee closer to wall
Keep torso upright
Tuck pelvis under for more stretch
Hold position and breathe
Switch sides
common_mistakes: Back knee too far from wall

modifications.easier: Foot on low surface, further from wall
modifications.harder: Reach arms overhead, knee closer to wall

exercises.name: Seated Hamstring Stretch
exercises.description: A seated stretch targeting the hamstrings performed on the floor. Stretching hamstrings helps reduce posterior knee tension.
instructions: Sit on floor with one leg extended
Bend other knee, foot against inner thigh
Sit tall and hinge forward from hips
Reach toward extended foot
Keep back as flat as possible
Feel stretch behind thigh
Hold and breathe

modifications.easier: Use strap around foot, slight knee bend
modifications.harder: Flex ankle, deeper forward fold

exercises.name: Standing IT Band Stretch
exercises.description: A standing stretch for the iliotibial band that can help reduce lateral knee pain. The IT band often contributes to patellofemoral issues.
instructions: Stand with side to wall, hand on wall for support
Cross outside leg behind inside leg
Push hips toward wall
Reach same-side arm overhead and toward wall
Feel stretch along outside of hip and thigh
Keep both feet flat on ground
Hold and switch sides
common_mistakes: Not pushing hips far enough toward wall
Not feeling stretch along lateral thigh

modifications.harder: Greater lean, longer holds

exercises.name: IT Band Foam Rolling
exercises.description: Self-myofascial release for the iliotibial band using a foam roller. Helps reduce tissue tension that can contribute to lateral knee pain.
instructions: Lie on side with foam roller under outer thigh
Support body with bottom forearm and top leg
Roll slowly from hip to just above knee
Pause on tender spots for 20-30 seconds
Avoid rolling directly on knee joint
Control pressure with supporting limbs
Roll entire length of IT band
common_mistakes: Too much or too little pressure

modifications.harder: Stack legs for more pressure

exercises.name: Quadriceps Foam Rolling
exercises.description: Self-myofascial release for the quadriceps muscles using a foam roller. Helps improve tissue quality and knee mobility.
instructions: Lie face down with foam roller under front of thighs
Support upper body on forearms
Roll from hip to just above kneecap
Move slowly, pausing on tender spots
Roll slightly inward and outward to cover all quads
Avoid rolling over kneecap
Breathe through tender areas

modifications.easier: One leg at a time, less body weight on roller
modifications.harder: Single leg, bend knee on tender spots

exercises.name: Wall Calf Stretch (Gastrocnemius)
exercises.description: A standing calf stretch targeting the gastrocnemius muscle. Calf flexibility affects knee mechanics during walking and stairs.
instructions: Stand facing wall with hands on wall at shoulder height
Step one leg back, keeping it straight
Keep back heel on ground, toes pointing forward
Lean into wall by bending front knee
Feel stretch in back of lower leg
Keep back knee straight throughout
Hold and switch sides

modifications.harder: Further from wall, greater lean

exercises.name: Balance Board - Two Legs
exercises.description: A balance exercise on an unstable surface that challenges proprioception and neuromuscular control. Important for ACL injury prevention.
instructions: Stand on balance board with feet shoulder-width
Keep knees slightly bent
Find your balance point
Try to keep board level
Start near wall for safety
Progress to eyes closed as able
Maintain for prescribed time
common_mistakes: Looking at feet instead of ahead

modifications.easier: Hold rail, foam pad instead of board
modifications.harder: Single leg, eyes closed, catch and throw ball

exercises.name: Single Leg Balance on Foam
exercises.description: Single leg stance on an unstable surface to challenge balance reactions and neuromuscular control around the knee.
instructions: Stand on foam pad or folded towel
Shift weight to one leg
Lift other foot off surface
Keep stance knee slightly bent
Maintain level pelvis
Hold as long as able with good form
Use wall for safety initially

modifications.harder: Eyes closed, head turns, arm movements

exercises.name: BOSU Ball Squat
exercises.description: A squat performed on the unstable surface of a BOSU ball. Challenges neuromuscular control while building functional strength.
instructions: Stand on dome side of BOSU, feet shoulder-width
Find your balance point
Perform controlled squat while maintaining balance
Keep knees tracking over toes
Lower to comfortable depth
Push through heels to stand
Keep movements controlled
common_mistakes: Going too deep and losing balance

modifications.easier: Nearby wall for touch support, partial squat
modifications.harder: Single leg, dome side down, add weights

exercises.name: Single Leg Clock Reach
exercises.description: A dynamic balance exercise reaching in multiple directions like clock positions. Challenges knee stability through various planes of motion.
instructions: Stand on one leg with slight knee bend
Reach other leg forward (12 oclock)
Return to center, then reach to side (3 or 9)
Return to center, then reach behind (6 oclock)
Continue through clock positions
Keep stance knee stable throughout
Maintain upright trunk

modifications.easier: Fingertip touch on wall, fewer positions
modifications.harder: On foam, hold weights, eyes closed

exercises.name: Lateral Hop and Stabilize
exercises.description: A plyometric exercise involving lateral jumping and landing stabilization. Develops dynamic knee control for sport-specific activities.
instructions: Stand on one leg with knee slightly bent
Hop sideways to land on same leg
Stick the landing with knee bent
Hold stable position for 2-3 seconds
Control any wobbling
Hop back to starting position
Focus on quiet, controlled landings

modifications.easier: Smaller hops, quick touch down allowed
modifications.harder: Larger hops, softer surface, multiple directions

exercises.name: Forward Hop and Stabilize
exercises.description: A single-leg forward hopping exercise with landing stabilization. Progresses dynamic knee control for return to running and sports.
instructions: Stand on one leg
Hop forward and land on same leg
Bend knee to absorb landing
Stabilize for 2-3 seconds
Control all wobbling before next hop
Progress distance as control improves
Land as quietly as possible

modifications.easier: Smaller hops, both legs, touch down allowed
modifications.harder: Continuous hopping, varied distances

exercises.name: Lunge
exercises.description: A fundamental lower body unilateral exercise that strengthens quadriceps, glutes, and hamstrings while improving balance and hip stability.
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart
Step forward with one leg, lowering hips until both knees are bent at approximately 90 degrees
Keep front knee directly above ankle, not pushing past toes
Keep torso upright and core engaged
Push off front foot to return to starting position
Repeat on the other side
common_mistakes: Rear knee touching the ground hard
Feet too narrow (walking on a tightrope)

modifications.easier: Reverse lunge (step back instead of forward), hold onto chair for balance
modifications.harder: Walking lunges, add weights

exercises.name: Lunge with Trunk Rotation
exercises.description: A walking or stationary lunge with rotational component that challenges knee stability in multiple planes of motion.
instructions: Step forward into lunge position
Lower until front thigh is parallel to ground
Keep front knee over ankle
Rotate trunk toward front leg
Hold rotation briefly
Return trunk to center
Push back to standing and repeat other side

modifications.easier: Stationary position, less rotation, shallower lunge
modifications.harder: Hold weight during rotation, walking lunges

exercises.name: Leg Press
exercises.description: A machine-based lower extremity strengthening exercise. Allows for heavy loading in a controlled environment with reduced balance demands.
instructions: Sit in leg press with back against pad
Place feet hip-width on platform
Release safety catches
Lower platform by bending knees
Stop at 90 degrees or comfortable depth
Push through heels to extend legs
Dont lock out knees at top
common_mistakes: Going too deep and rounding low back
Feet too high or low on platform

modifications.easier: Lighter weight, single leg with light load
modifications.harder: Heavier weight, single leg, pause at bottom

exercises.name: Leg Extension (Machine)
exercises.description: An open-chain quadriceps strengthening exercise on a machine. Isolates the quadriceps through full range of knee extension.
instructions: Sit with back against pad, knees at edge of seat
Adjust pad to rest on lower shins
Extend knees to straighten legs
Pause briefly at full extension
Lower slowly with control
Avoid locking out knees forcefully
Keep back pressed into seat
common_mistakes: Seat position too far forward or back

modifications.harder: Heavier weight, slow negatives, pause at top

contraindications: Acute ACL injury or early post-op

exercises.name: Hamstring Curl (Machine)
exercises.description: A machine-based hamstring strengthening exercise. Isolates the hamstrings through full range of knee flexion.
instructions: Lie face down or sit based on machine type
Adjust pad to rest on lower calves/Achilles
Curl heels toward buttocks
Squeeze hamstrings at top
Lower slowly with control
Keep hips pressed into pad
Avoid using momentum

modifications.harder: Heavier weight, single leg, pause at top

exercises.name: Box Squat
exercises.description: A squat to a box or chair that provides a consistent depth target and a moment of pause at the bottom. Teaches proper squat mechanics.
instructions: Stand in front of sturdy box or chair
Feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out
Push hips back and lower toward box
Lightly touch box with glutes
Pause briefly on box
Drive through heels to stand
Keep chest up throughout

modifications.easier: Higher box, use for sit to stand
modifications.harder: Lower box, add weight, pause longer

contraindications: Acute knee pain with deep flexion

exercises.name: Reverse Lunge
exercises.description: A lunge stepping backward rather than forward. Often better tolerated for those with knee issues as the front knee stays more stable.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Step one leg backward into lunge
Lower until front thigh is parallel to floor
Keep front knee over ankle
Push through front heel to return to standing
Alternate legs or complete all reps on one side
Maintain upright posture
common_mistakes: Step too short or too long

modifications.harder: Add dumbbells, pulse at bottom, deficit lunge

exercises.name: Curtsy Lunge
exercises.description: A lunge variation crossing the back leg behind the front leg. Emphasizes gluteus medius and challenges frontal plane stability.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Step one leg behind and across the other
Lower into lunge position
Keep front knee tracking over toes
Push through front heel to return
Avoid letting front knee cave inward
Keep hips facing forward as much as possible

modifications.harder: Add weight, pulse at bottom

exercises.name: Ankle Alphabet
exercises.description: Drawing letters with your foot to move the ankle through all planes of motion. A gentle way to restore mobility after injury.
instructions: Sit with leg extended or hanging off edge of bed
Keep leg still, moving only at the ankle
Trace the letters of the alphabet with your big toe
Make letters as large as comfortable
Go through entire alphabet A to Z
Focus on smooth, controlled movements
Can do uppercase and lowercase for more work
common_mistakes: Moving from knee instead of ankle

modifications.harder: Larger letters, add resistance band

exercises.name: Ankle Circles
exercises.description: Circular movements of the ankle to maintain or restore joint mobility. Simple exercise that can be done anywhere.
instructions: Sit or lie with leg relaxed
Rotate foot in circular motion from the ankle
Make circles as large as comfortable
Complete prescribed reps clockwise
Then complete same number counterclockwise
Keep leg still, movement only from ankle
Move slowly and smoothly

modifications.harder: Larger circles, add resistance band

exercises.name: Ankle Pumps
exercises.description: Alternating dorsiflexion and plantarflexion to maintain mobility and promote circulation. Often one of the first exercises after ankle injury or surgery.
instructions: Sit or lie with legs extended
Pull toes up toward shin (dorsiflex)
Then point toes away (plantarflex)
Move through full available range
Keep knees straight
Move both ankles together or one at a time
Pump continuously for set duration
common_mistakes: Stopping at end ranges instead of pumping

modifications.harder: Add resistance band, hold at each end

exercises.name: Towel Scrunches
exercises.description: Gripping and scrunching a towel with the toes to strengthen intrinsic foot muscles. Helps with arch support and toe function.
instructions: Sit in chair with bare foot on towel
Keep heel on ground
Curl toes to scrunch towel toward you
Release and spread toes
Scrunch towel again
Continue until towel is fully gathered
Spread towel out and repeat
common_mistakes: Foot not flat on towel at start

modifications.harder: Thicker towel, add weight on towel

exercises.name: Marble Pickup
exercises.description: Picking up small objects with the toes to improve toe dexterity and intrinsic foot muscle strength. Functional exercise for foot control.
instructions: Sit in chair with bare feet on floor
Place marbles or small objects on floor
Pick up marble by gripping with toes
Lift and place in nearby container
Repeat with next marble
Use all toes to grip, not just big toe
Complete with both feet

modifications.harder: Smaller objects, standing, timed challenge

exercises.name: Seated Calf Raise
exercises.description: A calf exercise targeting the soleus muscle performed seated. The bent knee position emphasizes the soleus over the gastrocnemius.
instructions: Sit on chair with feet flat on floor
Knees bent at 90 degrees
Raise heels as high as possible
Keep balls of feet on ground
Squeeze calf muscles at top
Lower slowly with control
Can add weight on knees for resistance
common_mistakes: Feet positioned too far forward or back

modifications.harder: Add weight on knees, single leg, pause at top

exercises.name: Standing Calf Raise
exercises.description: A standing exercise to strengthen the gastrocnemius muscle. Fundamental for push-off strength in walking and running.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Hold wall or chair for balance if needed
Rise up onto balls of feet
Lift heels as high as possible
Squeeze calf muscles at top
Lower slowly with control
Keep knees straight throughout

modifications.harder: Single leg, off edge of step, add weight

exercises.name: Single Leg Calf Raise
exercises.description: An advanced calf raise performed on one leg to build strength for walking, running, and jumping activities.
instructions: Stand on one leg near wall for balance
Lift other foot off ground
Rise up onto ball of foot
Lift heel as high as possible
Lower slowly with control
Complete all reps before switching
Keep movement smooth and controlled

modifications.harder: Off edge of step, add dumbbell, eyes closed

exercises.name: Eccentric Heel Drop
exercises.description: An eccentric exercise emphasizing the lowering phase. Primary exercise for Achilles tendinopathy rehabilitation (Alfredson protocol).
instructions: Stand on step with heels hanging off edge
Rise up on both feet (or use uninjured leg)
Shift weight to injured/target leg
Slowly lower heel below step level
Take 3-5 seconds for the lowering phase
Use both legs to rise back up
Focus on slow, controlled descent
common_mistakes: Using target leg to push up

modifications.easier: Bilateral lowering, bent knee for soleus
modifications.harder: Add weight (backpack), slower tempo

exercises.name: Bent Knee Eccentric Heel Drop
exercises.description: An eccentric calf exercise with knee bent to target the soleus and lower portion of the Achilles tendon.
instructions: Stand on step with heels off edge
Bend knees to about 30 degrees
Rise up on both feet
Shift weight to target leg
Slowly lower heel below step, keeping knee bent
Take 3-5 seconds for lowering
Use both legs to rise, maintaining knee bend
common_mistakes: Not dropping heel below step level

modifications.harder: Add weight, slower tempo

exercises.name: Toe Raises (Heel Walking)
exercises.description: Lifting toes off ground to strengthen the tibialis anterior. Important for foot clearance during walking and preventing shin splints.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Hold wall for balance if needed
Lift toes and forefeet off ground
Keep heels on ground
Walk forward on heels only
Take 10-15 steps
Lower and repeat
common_mistakes: Walking on flat feet instead of heels

modifications.harder: Longer distances, backward heel walking

exercises.name: Resisted Dorsiflexion
exercises.description: Ankle dorsiflexion against resistance band to strengthen the anterior tibialis. Important for foot clearance and walking mechanics.
instructions: Sit with leg extended, band around forefoot
Anchor band to sturdy object in front
Pull toes toward shin against resistance
Hold at end range briefly
Slowly return to starting position
Keep knee straight throughout
Control both directions of movement

modifications.harder: Heavier band, more reps, slower tempo

exercises.name: Resisted Plantarflexion
exercises.description: Ankle plantarflexion against resistance band to strengthen calf muscles. Useful when weight-bearing calf exercises are too challenging.
instructions: Sit with leg extended, band around forefoot
Hold band ends with hands
Point toes away from body against resistance
Hold at end range briefly
Slowly return to starting position
Keep knee straight
Control the movement in both directions

modifications.harder: Heavier band, single leg, pause at end

exercises.name: Resisted Ankle Inversion
exercises.description: Turning the foot inward against resistance to strengthen the invertors. Important for arch support and ankle stability.
instructions: Sit with legs extended, band around forefoot
Anchor band to outside (lateral side)
Turn sole of foot inward against band
Keep knee and leg still
Hold at end range briefly
Return slowly with control
Isolate movement to ankle joint only
common_mistakes: Rotating from hip instead of ankle

modifications.harder: Heavier band, more reps

exercises.name: Resisted Ankle Eversion
exercises.description: Turning the foot outward against resistance to strengthen the peroneal muscles. Critical for preventing recurrent lateral ankle sprains.
instructions: Sit with legs extended, band around forefoot
Anchor band to inside (medial side)
Turn sole of foot outward against band
Keep knee and leg still
Hold at end range briefly
Return slowly with control
Isolate movement to ankle joint

modifications.harder: Heavier band, pause at end range

exercises.name: Gastrocnemius Stretch (Wall)
exercises.description: A standing calf stretch with knee straight targeting the gastrocnemius muscle. Essential for restoring ankle dorsiflexion range.
instructions: Face wall with hands at shoulder height
Step back with leg to be stretched
Keep back knee straight, heel on ground
Lean into wall, bending front knee
Feel stretch in back of calf
Keep back foot pointing forward
Hold and breathe

modifications.harder: Toes on wall for deeper stretch

exercises.name: Soleus Stretch (Wall)
exercises.description: A calf stretch with knee bent targeting the soleus muscle. Important for deep calf flexibility and Achilles health.
instructions: Face wall with hands at shoulder height
Step back with leg to stretch
Bend BOTH knees while keeping back heel down
Lower hips slightly toward ground
Feel stretch lower in calf, near Achilles
Keep back heel firmly on ground
Hold and breathe
common_mistakes: Keeping back knee straight (thats gastroc stretch)

modifications.easier: Less knee bend, closer to wall
modifications.harder: Deeper knee bend, longer holds

exercises.name: Step Calf Stretch
exercises.description: A calf stretch using a step to drop the heel below foot level. Provides a deeper stretch than wall stretching.
instructions: Stand on step with balls of feet on edge
Hold rail for balance
Let one heel drop below step level
Keep that knee straight for gastroc
Feel deep stretch in calf
Hold at comfortable stretch
Switch legs

modifications.harder: Bent knee for soleus, longer holds

exercises.name: Plantar Fascia Stretch
exercises.description: A stretch for the plantar fascia on the bottom of the foot. Key exercise for plantar fasciitis treatment.
instructions: Sit and cross affected foot over opposite knee
Grasp toes and pull them back toward shin
You should see arch heighten
Feel stretch along bottom of foot
Can palpate plantar fascia to confirm stretch
Hold for prescribed duration
Especially important first thing in morning

modifications.harder: Massage fascia while holding stretch

exercises.name: Frozen Bottle Roll
exercises.description: Rolling foot over frozen water bottle for combined massage and ice therapy. Effective for plantar fasciitis symptoms.
instructions: Freeze water bottle overnight
Sit in chair with bottle on floor
Place arch of foot on bottle
Roll foot back and forth over bottle
Apply moderate pressure
Roll from heel to ball of foot
Continue for 5-10 minutes

modifications.harder: Golf ball for more targeted pressure

exercises.name: Achilles Tendon Stretch
exercises.description: A gentle stretch specifically for the Achilles tendon. Important for maintaining tendon health and flexibility.
instructions: Stand on step with heels hanging off edge
Hold rail for support
Slowly lower heels below step level
Stop when you feel mild stretch
Hold position and breathe
Rise back up slowly
This is a gentle sustained stretch, not exercise
common_mistakes: One foot working harder than other

modifications.easier: Less heel drop, flat ground stretch
modifications.harder: Single leg, longer holds

exercises.name: Single Leg Stance
exercises.description: Standing on one leg to challenge ankle proprioception and stability. Foundation exercise for ankle sprain rehabilitation.
instructions: Stand near wall or chair for safety
Shift weight to one leg
Lift other foot slightly off ground
Find your balance point
Focus on a fixed point ahead
Hold as long as possible with good form
Switch legs

modifications.harder: Eyes closed, foam pad, head turns

contraindications: Acute ankle sprain (wait for weight-bearing clearance)

exercises.name: Single Leg Stance Eyes Closed
exercises.description: Single leg balance with eyes closed to maximize proprioceptive challenge. Removes visual input to force reliance on ankle feedback.
instructions: Stand near wall for safety (dont touch)
Stand on one leg with good balance
When stable, close eyes
Try to maintain balance
Feel ankle making constant corrections
Open eyes if losing balance
Progress duration over time
common_mistakes: Not being stable before closing eyes
Standing too far from safety support

modifications.easier: Light touch on wall, brief eye closure
modifications.harder: On foam, head movements

exercises.name: Wobble Board Balance (Two Legs)
exercises.description: Balancing on an unstable wobble board to challenge ankle proprioception. Key exercise for ankle sprain prevention.
instructions: Stand on wobble board with feet shoulder-width
Keep knees slightly bent
Try to keep board level
Dont let edges touch ground
Make small corrections with ankles
Start near wall for safety
Progress to unsupported
common_mistakes: Looking at board instead of ahead
Standing too narrow or too wide

modifications.harder: Single leg, eyes closed, ball toss

exercises.name: Wobble Board Balance (Single Leg)
exercises.description: Single leg balance on wobble board for advanced ankle proprioception training. Final progression in ankle stability training.
instructions: Stand on wobble board on one leg
Keep knee slightly bent
Try to keep board level
Make corrections from ankle, not hip
Start near wall for safety
Hold as long as possible
Switch legs
common_mistakes: Using hip strategy instead of ankle

modifications.easier: Fingertip touch on wall, rocker board
modifications.harder: Eyes closed, ball toss, head movements

exercises.name: Foam Pad Balance
exercises.description: Standing on compliant foam surface to challenge ankle stability. Intermediate progression between firm ground and wobble board.
instructions: Stand on foam balance pad
Start with both feet
Progress to single leg when ready
Keep knees slightly bent
Feel ankles making corrections
Maintain upright posture
Progress hold time

modifications.harder: Thicker foam, eyes closed, arm movements

exercises.name: Tandem Stance (Heel to Toe)
exercises.description: Standing with feet in line, heel touching toe, to challenge balance in a narrow base of support.
instructions: Stand near wall for safety
Place one foot directly in front of other
Heel of front foot touches toes of back foot
Keep feet in a straight line
Arms out to sides for balance
Hold position
Switch which foot is in front

modifications.easier: Small gap between feet, wall touch
modifications.harder: Eyes closed, on foam, arms crossed

exercises.name: Tandem Walking (Heel to Toe)
exercises.description: Walking in a straight line with heel touching toe each step. Challenges dynamic balance and ankle control.
instructions: Walk along a straight line (real or imaginary)
Place heel of front foot against toes of back foot
Keep feet in straight line
Arms out for balance
Look ahead, not at feet
Take 10-15 steps
Turn and walk back
common_mistakes: Feet not touching heel to toe

modifications.harder: Arms crossed, eyes on horizon, backwards

exercises.name: Toe Walking
exercises.description: Walking on toes to strengthen calf muscles and practice push-off mechanics. Functional progression for calf strengthening.
instructions: Stand tall near wall for safety
Rise up onto balls of feet
Walk forward staying on toes
Take 15-20 steps
Keep heels off ground throughout
Maintain upright posture
Lower and rest, then repeat

modifications.harder: Longer distances, incline, weighted

exercises.name: Heel Walking
exercises.description: Walking on heels with toes lifted to strengthen anterior tibialis. Helps prevent shin splints and improves foot clearance.
instructions: Stand near wall for safety
Lift toes and forefeet off ground
Walk forward on heels only
Keep toes pulled up throughout
Take 15-20 steps
Maintain upright posture
Lower and rest, then repeat

modifications.harder: Longer distances, backward walking

exercises.name: Lateral Hops (Ankle)
exercises.description: Side-to-side hopping to challenge dynamic ankle stability. Late-stage rehabilitation exercise for return to sport.
instructions: Stand on one leg
Hop sideways, landing on same foot
Stick the landing with soft knee
Control any wobbling
Hop back to starting position
Maintain alignment throughout
Focus on quiet, controlled landings
common_mistakes: Not sticking landing before next hop

modifications.harder: Larger hops, eyes closed at landing, softer surface

exercises.name: Forward Hops (Ankle)
exercises.description: Forward hopping on one leg to develop dynamic ankle control for running and jumping activities.
instructions: Stand on one leg
Hop forward, landing on same foot
Absorb landing with soft knee
Stabilize completely before next hop
Progress distance as control improves
Land as quietly as possible
Complete prescribed reps then switch legs
common_mistakes: Using too much hip to land

modifications.harder: Continuous hopping, varied surfaces

exercises.name: Four Square Hops
exercises.description: Hopping in a square pattern in four directions to challenge ankle stability in multiple planes. Sport-specific training.
instructions: Create or imagine a cross pattern on floor
Start in one quadrant on one leg
Hop forward to next quadrant
Stabilize, then hop sideways
Continue around the square
Reverse direction
Land and stabilize each hop

modifications.easier: Two legs, walk the pattern first
modifications.harder: Timed for speed, multiple rounds

exercises.name: Jump Rope (or Simulation)
exercises.description: Jumping rope or simulating the motion to build calf endurance and rhythmic ankle control. Excellent for return to activity.
instructions: Stand with feet together
Jump using primarily ankles and calves
Stay on balls of feet
Land softly with slight knee bend
Keep jumps low (1-2 inches)
Maintain rhythm
Can use actual rope or simulate

modifications.harder: Single leg, high speed, actual rope tricks

exercises.name: Walking Lunges (Ankle Focus)
exercises.description: Walking lunge with attention to ankle stability and push-off. Functional exercise combining strength and balance.
instructions: Take a large step forward into lunge
Lower until back knee nearly touches ground
Keep front ankle stable - no wobbling
Push through front foot to step through
Continue walking forward with alternating lunges
Focus on ankle stability at push-off
Maintain upright posture

modifications.harder: Add weight, walking on grass/sand

exercises.name: Lateral Step-Up (Ankle Focus)
exercises.description: Side step onto elevated surface focusing on ankle stability. Combines strength with lateral balance challenge.
instructions: Stand beside step or platform
Step up sideways, placing whole foot on step
Press through that foot to bring other leg up
Control the ankle - no wobbling
Step back down with control
Focus on quiet, stable footwork
Complete all reps before switching sides
common_mistakes: Not placing whole foot on step

modifications.harder: Higher step, add weight, pause at top

exercises.name: Single Leg Squat (Ankle Focus)
exercises.description: Single leg squat with focus on ankle alignment and stability. High-level exercise for ankle rehabilitation.
instructions: Stand on one leg near support
Slowly lower into single leg squat
Focus on keeping ankle stable
Dont let ankle roll in or out
Lower as far as you can control
Push back up through stable ankle
Watch for any ankle wobbling
common_mistakes: Weight shifting to outside of foot

modifications.harder: Full depth, on foam, eyes closed

exercises.name: Agility Ladder Drills
exercises.description: Quick footwork patterns through agility ladder to develop rapid ankle control. Sport-specific training for return to athletics.
instructions: Lay agility ladder on ground
Start at one end
Step through squares with quick feet
Keep on balls of feet
Stay light and springy
Progress to more complex patterns
Focus on quick, controlled foot placement
common_mistakes: Looking at feet instead of ahead
Going too fast before mastering pattern

modifications.harder: Full speed, complex patterns, lateral movements
