exercises.name: Short Foot Exercise
exercises.description: Activating intrinsic foot muscles to raise the arch without toe flexion. Foundational exercise for foot stability.
instructions: Sit with bare foot flat on floor
Keep toes relaxed and flat
Try to dome the arch by pulling ball of foot toward heel
The foot should shorten slightly
Do not curl toes - keep them flat
Hold the arch dome position
Relax and repeat
common_mistakes: Using calf instead of foot muscles

modifications.harder: Standing, single leg, during activities

exercises.name: Toe Yoga
exercises.description: Independent toe movement exercises to improve motor control of individual toes. Restores foot dexterity.
instructions: Sit with bare feet flat on floor
Lift only big toe while keeping others down
Then keep big toe down, lift other four toes
Alternate between these movements
Work on smooth, controlled transitions
Progress to spreading toes apart
Practice lifting individual toes
common_mistakes: Tensing foot instead of individual toes

modifications.harder: Lift each toe individually, eyes closed

exercises.name: Walking on Inside of Feet
exercises.description: Walking with feet rolled slightly inward to strengthen peroneal muscles. Helps prevent lateral ankle sprains.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Slightly roll weight to inside of feet
Walk forward maintaining this position
Keep gentle pressure on inside of feet
Take 15-20 steps
Avoid excessive inversion or knee strain
Return and repeat

modifications.harder: Longer distances, slower pace

exercises.name: Walking on Outside of Feet
exercises.description: Walking with feet rolled slightly outward to strengthen invertors. Helps with arch support and medial ankle stability.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Slightly roll weight to outside of feet
Walk forward maintaining this position
Keep gentle pressure on outside of feet
Take 15-20 steps
Avoid excessive supination
Return and repeat
common_mistakes: Walking on lateral foot edge only

modifications.harder: Longer distances, more deliberate

exercises.name: Calf Raise Progression Series
exercises.description: Progressive calf raise series from bilateral to single leg. Systematic approach to rebuilding calf strength.
instructions: Start with bilateral calf raises (both legs)
Progress to single leg with support
Then single leg without support
Finally single leg off edge of step
Perform 15 reps at each progression
Only advance when current level is easy
Focus on full range of motion

modifications.harder: Add weight at each level

exercises.name: Reactive Balance Taps
exercises.description: Quick balance recovery exercise tapping foot in different directions. Develops reactive ankle control.
instructions: Stand on one leg
Quickly tap other foot forward, return to center
Tap to side, return to center
Tap behind, return to center
Keep stance leg stable throughout
Increase speed as control improves
Focus on stable ankle during all taps
common_mistakes: Taps too small to challenge balance

modifications.harder: Faster taps, on foam, eyes closed

exercises.name: Perturbation Balance Training
exercises.description: Balance training with external perturbations to challenge reactive ankle stability. Advanced sport-specific training.
instructions: Stand on one leg with partner nearby
Partner gives small pushes in different directions
Recover balance using ankle strategy
Keep core engaged
Progress to eyes closed
Partner varies timing and direction
Maintain single leg stance throughout

modifications.harder: Larger pushes, unpredictable, on foam

exercises.name: Ball of Foot Raises
exercises.description: Rising onto balls of feet in various positions to build calf strength. Basic progression before single leg work.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Rise up onto balls of feet
Lift heels as high as possible
Balance briefly at top
Lower slowly with control
Keep weight even on both feet
Squeeze calves at top of each rep

modifications.harder: Single leg, off edge of step

exercises.name: Supine Ankle Dorsiflexion Stretch
exercises.description: Using a strap to assist ankle dorsiflexion while lying down. Gentle way to improve dorsiflexion range.
instructions: Lie on back with legs extended
Loop strap around ball of foot
Keep leg straight on ground
Gently pull strap to flex ankle
Pull toes toward shin
Hold at comfortable stretch
Keep knee straight

modifications.harder: Longer holds, more pull, straight knee stretch on wall

exercises.name: Half Kneeling Ankle Mobilization
exercises.description: Weight-bearing ankle dorsiflexion stretch in half kneeling position. Effective for improving functional ankle mobility.
instructions: Kneel with one foot forward, flat on ground
Back knee on pad
Keep front heel down
Drive front knee forward over toes
Knee should track over second toe
Feel stretch in front of ankle
Rock in and out of stretch
common_mistakes: Not driving knee far enough forward

modifications.harder: Band around ankle pulling backward

exercises.name: Banded Ankle Distraction
exercises.description: Using resistance band to create joint distraction while mobilizing ankle. Helps improve dorsiflexion by creating space in joint.
instructions: Anchor heavy band low on stable object
Loop band around front of ankle
Step away to create tension (band pulls backward)
Get into half kneeling or lunge position
Drive knee forward while band pulls ankle back
Feel joint opening in front of ankle
Rock in and out of end range
common_mistakes: Band too high on leg (should be at ankle crease)

modifications.harder: Heavier band, longer holds, add oscillations

exercises.name: Star Balance Reach
exercises.description: Single leg stance with reaches in 8 directions like a star pattern. Tests and builds dynamic ankle stability. Based on the Y-Balance Test.
instructions: Stand on one leg at center of star pattern
Reach other leg as far as possible in each direction
Touch toe lightly to ground at end range
Return to center with control
Complete all 8 directions
Maintain stance leg stability throughout
Do not shift weight to reaching leg

modifications.harder: On foam pad, eyes closed between reaches

exercises.name: Side-Lying External Rotation
exercises.description: A foundational rotator cuff exercise targeting the infraspinatus and teres minor. Key exercise for shoulder stability and injury prevention.
instructions: Lie on your side with affected arm on top
Bend elbow to 90 degrees, arm against side
Hold light dumbbell or no weight
Rotate forearm toward ceiling
Keep elbow pinned to side
Lower slowly with control
Avoid rolling backward

modifications.easier: No weight, towel roll under elbow
modifications.harder: Add weight, slower tempo

exercises.name: Standing External Rotation (Band)
exercises.description: A standing rotator cuff exercise using resistance band for external rotation strengthening. Convenient exercise for home or gym.
instructions: Stand with elbow bent 90 degrees, arm at side
Hold band anchored at elbow height
Rotate forearm away from body
Keep elbow pinned to side
Control return to starting position
Maintain upright posture
Avoid body rotation

modifications.easier: Lighter band, towel between elbow and side
modifications.harder: Heavier band, 90/90 position

exercises.name: Prone Horizontal Abduction
exercises.description: A prone exercise targeting the posterior shoulder and rotator cuff. Also known as the prone T or reverse fly.
instructions: Lie face down on bench or mat
Arms hanging down, thumbs pointing out
Raise arms out to sides to shoulder height
Squeeze shoulder blades together
Hold briefly at top
Lower slowly with control
Keep thumbs pointing toward ceiling
common_mistakes: Thumbs pointing down instead of up

modifications.easier: No weight, on floor with pillow under chest
modifications.harder: Add light dumbbells, hold at top

exercises.name: Prone Y Raise
exercises.description: A prone exercise for lower trapezius and posterior shoulder. Creates a Y shape with arms, targeting scapular stability.
instructions: Lie face down on bench or mat
Arms hanging down in Y position (45 degrees from head)
Thumbs pointing up
Raise arms in Y formation
Squeeze lower shoulder blades together
Hold at top briefly
Lower with control
common_mistakes: Arms too close to head (I instead of Y)
Arms too wide (T instead of Y)
Using upper traps instead of lower

modifications.harder: Add light dumbbells, longer holds

exercises.name: Prone W Raise
exercises.description: A prone exercise combining external rotation with horizontal abduction. Creates a W shape with the arms.
instructions: Lie face down on bench
Elbows bent 90 degrees, at shoulder level
Forearms hanging down
Raise elbows while rotating forearms up
Create W shape with arms at top
Squeeze shoulder blades together
Lower with control

modifications.harder: Add light dumbbells

exercises.name: Standing Internal Rotation (Band)
exercises.description: A band exercise targeting the subscapularis muscle for internal rotation strength. Important for shoulder stability.
instructions: Stand with elbow bent 90 degrees, arm at side
Hold band anchored at elbow height to your side
Rotate forearm across body toward belly
Keep elbow pinned to side
Control return to starting position
Maintain upright posture
Avoid leaning or twisting

modifications.harder: Heavier band, 90/90 position

exercises.name: 90/90 External Rotation
exercises.description: External rotation with arm at 90 degrees abduction. Strengthens rotator cuff in the throwing or overhead position.
instructions: Stand or lie with shoulder at 90 degrees abduction
Elbow bent to 90 degrees (arm like goal post)
Hold light weight or band
Rotate forearm up toward ceiling
Keep elbow at shoulder height
Lower slowly to starting position
Maintain shoulder blade stability

modifications.harder: Add weight, standing with band

exercises.name: Scapular Squeeze (Retraction)
exercises.description: Squeezing shoulder blades together to strengthen the rhomboids and middle trapezius. Foundation for good posture.
instructions: Sit or stand with arms at sides
Pull shoulders back and down
Squeeze shoulder blades together
Imagine holding a pencil between them
Hold for prescribed time
Relax and repeat
Avoid shrugging shoulders up

modifications.harder: Longer holds, against resistance band

exercises.name: Wall Push-Up Plus
exercises.description: A modified push-up emphasizing scapular protraction to strengthen the serratus anterior. The plus refers to extra protraction at top.
instructions: Stand facing wall, arms extended
Place hands on wall at shoulder height
Perform a push-up into the wall
At the end, push extra to protract scapulae
Shoulder blades should spread apart
Allow shoulder blades to come together on return
Focus on the extra protraction at end
common_mistakes: Not moving shoulder blades at all

modifications.harder: Counter, floor push-up plus

exercises.name: Seated Row (Band)
exercises.description: A rowing movement using resistance band to strengthen the posterior shoulder and scapular retractors. Excellent for posture.
instructions: Sit with legs extended, band around feet
Hold band with both hands
Sit tall with shoulders back
Pull band toward lower chest
Squeeze shoulder blades together
Keep elbows close to body
Return slowly with control

modifications.harder: Heavier band, pause at contraction

contraindications: Acute shoulder pain with rowing motion

exercises.name: Face Pull
exercises.description: A cable or band exercise targeting the rear deltoids, rotator cuff, and scapular stabilizers. Excellent for counteracting forward shoulder posture.
instructions: Hold band anchored at face height
Pull band toward face, separating hands
Finish with hands beside ears, elbows high
Externally rotate shoulders at end
Squeeze shoulder blades together
Return with control
Keep wrists straight

modifications.harder: Heavier band, pause at contraction

exercises.name: Band Pull-Apart
exercises.description: Pulling a band apart in front of the body to work the posterior shoulder and scapular muscles. Great warm-up or postural exercise.
instructions: Hold band in front with arms extended
Arms at shoulder height
Pull band apart by squeezing shoulder blades
Bring band to chest level
Keep arms straight or slightly bent
Return with control
Avoid shrugging shoulders

modifications.harder: Heavier band, narrower grip, pause at end

exercises.name: Shoulder Shrugs
exercises.description: Elevating the shoulders to strengthen the upper trapezius. Note: not always indicated as upper traps are often overactive.
instructions: Stand with weights at sides (or no weight)
Keep arms straight
Elevate shoulders toward ears
Hold briefly at top
Lower slowly with control
Keep neck relaxed
Move straight up and down

modifications.harder: Add dumbbells, pause at top

exercises.name: Scapular Push-Up
exercises.description: A push-up variation focusing only on scapular movement without bending elbows. Isolates the serratus anterior.
instructions: Get into plank position (or from knees)
Keep arms straight throughout
Allow shoulder blades to pinch together
Then push to spread them apart
Movement is only at shoulder blades
Elbows stay locked
Focus on the protraction/retraction

modifications.harder: Full push-up position, hold at end ranges

exercises.name: Low Trapezius Raise
exercises.description: An exercise specifically targeting the lower trapezius for scapular depression and upward rotation. Often weak in those with shoulder problems.
instructions: Lie prone on incline bench or stand hinged forward
Arms hanging in Y position (about 120 degrees)
Thumbs up position
Raise arms while squeezing lower shoulder blades
Initiate movement from lower traps, not shoulders
Hold at top briefly
Lower with control

modifications.harder: Add light dumbbells, longer holds

exercises.name: Cross-Body Shoulder Stretch
exercises.description: A stretch for the posterior shoulder capsule and muscles. Common stretch for tightness from throwing or overhead activities.
instructions: Bring arm across your body at chest height
Use other hand to pull above the elbow
Keep shoulder blade stable (dont let it tip forward)
Feel stretch in back of shoulder
Hold and breathe
Avoid shrugging the stretching shoulder
Switch sides
common_mistakes: Pulling on the elbow joint itself

modifications.harder: Lean into wall for added stretch

exercises.name: Sleeper Stretch
exercises.description: A side-lying stretch for internal rotation and posterior capsule tightness. Common in throwing athletes with GIRD (glenohumeral internal rotation deficit).
instructions: Lie on affected side
Position shoulder at 90 degrees from body
Elbow bent to 90 degrees
Use other hand to push forearm toward floor
Keep shoulder blade stabilized against ground
Feel stretch in back of shoulder
Gentle sustained pressure

modifications.harder: Shoulder slightly above 90 degrees

exercises.name: Doorway Pectoral Stretch
exercises.description: A stretch for the pectoral muscles using a doorframe. Essential for counteracting forward shoulder posture.
instructions: Stand in doorway
Place forearm on door frame, elbow at shoulder height
Step through doorway with same-side foot
Rotate trunk away until stretch is felt
Keep core engaged, dont arch back
Hold and breathe
Vary elbow height to stretch different fibers

modifications.harder: Both arms simultaneously, deeper step

exercises.name: Overhead Triceps Stretch
exercises.description: A stretch for the triceps and lateral shoulder. Also stretches the latissimus dorsi when combined with side bend.
instructions: Raise one arm overhead
Bend elbow, reaching hand down back
Use other hand to gently push elbow back
Feel stretch along back of arm
Keep head upright, dont push forward
Hold and breathe
Switch sides
common_mistakes: Not keeping arm close to head

modifications.harder: Add side bend for lat stretch

exercises.name: Wall Lat Stretch
exercises.description: A stretch for the latissimus dorsi using a wall for support. Important for overhead shoulder mobility.
instructions: Stand facing wall, arms length away
Place palms on wall at shoulder height
Step back and hinge forward at hips
Press chest toward floor
Feel stretch under arms and along sides
Keep spine neutral
Breathe into the stretch

modifications.harder: Hands closer together, deeper hinge

exercises.name: Towel Stretch (Internal Rotation)
exercises.description: Using a towel behind the back to stretch into internal rotation. Helpful for activities requiring reaching behind back.
instructions: Hold towel in top hand over shoulder
Reach other hand behind back to grasp towel
Top hand gently pulls towel upward
Feel stretch in shoulder of lower arm
Keep upright posture
Hold at comfortable stretch
Switch arm positions

modifications.harder: Shorter grip, more pull

exercises.name: Pendulum Exercise
exercises.description: A gentle mobilization exercise using gravity and momentum to move the shoulder. Often first exercise after shoulder surgery.
instructions: Lean forward, support yourself on table/chair
Let affected arm hang down relaxed
Shift body weight to create arm movement
Move arm in small circles
Circle in both directions
Also try forward/back and side to side
Keep shoulder muscles relaxed
common_mistakes: Using shoulder muscles to move arm

modifications.harder: Hold light weight, larger circles

exercises.name: Wall Slides
exercises.description: Sliding arms up and down a wall to improve shoulder flexion while maintaining scapular control. Also known as wall angels.
instructions: Stand with back against wall
Arms at sides, elbows and wrists against wall
Slide arms up wall as high as possible
Keep elbows, wrists, and back in contact
Slide back down with control
Maintain lower back against wall
Move slowly and with control

modifications.harder: Hold weight, pause at top

exercises.name: Shoulder Circles
exercises.description: Arm circles to warm up and mobilize the shoulder joint. Good preparation for exercise.
instructions: Stand with arms at sides
Make small circles with arms
Gradually increase circle size
Circle forward then backward
Keep posture upright
Move at controlled pace
Let arms relax

modifications.harder: Hold light weights, larger circles

exercises.name: Supine Shoulder Flexion (Wand)
exercises.description: Using a wand or cane while lying down to assist shoulder flexion. Good for regaining overhead motion after injury.
instructions: Lie on back holding wand with both hands
Keep elbows straight
Use good arm to help lift both arms overhead
Go as far as comfortable
Hold briefly at end range
Lower slowly with control
Keep lower back flat

modifications.harder: Longer holds, less assistance

exercises.name: Supine External Rotation (Wand)
exercises.description: Wand-assisted external rotation stretch while lying down. Helps regain rotational range of motion.
instructions: Lie on back with elbow bent 90 degrees at side
Hold wand with both hands
Use good arm to push affected arm into external rotation
Forearm rotates outward, away from body
Keep elbow against side
Hold at end range
Return with control

modifications.harder: Longer holds, arm slightly abducted

exercises.name: Table Slide Flexion
exercises.description: Sliding hands forward on a table to improve shoulder flexion. Uses gravity assist and is easy to control.
instructions: Sit at table with forearms on surface
Slide hands forward on table
Let trunk lean forward as arms slide
Feel stretch in shoulders as arms extend
Hold at end range
Slide back to starting position
Keep movements smooth

modifications.easier: Towel under hands for easier sliding
modifications.harder: Longer holds, further reach

exercises.name: Scaption (Scapular Plane Raise)
exercises.description: Raising the arm in the scapular plane (30-45 degrees forward). Targets supraspinatus with reduced impingement risk.
instructions: Stand with arms at sides, thumbs up
Raise arms forward at 45 degree angle from body
This is the scapular plane
Raise to shoulder height
Keep thumbs pointing up
Lower with control
Maintain good posture
common_mistakes: Arms too far forward or to sides

modifications.harder: Add dumbbells, slower tempo

exercises.name: Lateral Raise
exercises.description: Raising arms out to the sides to strengthen the lateral deltoid. Common shoulder strengthening exercise.
instructions: Stand with arms at sides, weights in hands
Raise arms out to sides
Stop at shoulder height
Keep slight bend in elbows
Lower slowly with control
Lead with elbows, not hands
Avoid shrugging
common_mistakes: Arms going forward instead of to sides

modifications.harder: Heavier weight, pause at top

exercises.name: Front Raise
exercises.description: Raising arms forward to strengthen the anterior deltoid. Common exercise for shoulder flexion strength.
instructions: Stand with arms at sides, weights in hands
Raise one or both arms forward
Stop at shoulder height
Keep arms straight or slight elbow bend
Lower slowly with control
Maintain upright posture
Alternate arms or both together

modifications.harder: Heavier weight, both arms, pause at top

exercises.name: Reverse Fly
exercises.description: A bent-over exercise targeting the rear deltoids and upper back. Excellent for posture and shoulder balance.
instructions: Bend forward at hips, back flat
Hold weights hanging down, palms facing each other
Raise arms out to sides, squeezing shoulder blades
Stop at shoulder height
Lower slowly with control
Keep slight bend in elbows
Maintain flat back throughout

modifications.easier: No weight, chest supported on incline bench
modifications.harder: Heavier weight, pause at top

exercises.name: Push-Up (Modified)
exercises.description: A modified push-up focusing on shoulder stability and chest strengthening. Can be done from knees or wall.
instructions: Start in push-up position (knees or toes)
Hands slightly wider than shoulder width
Lower chest toward floor
Keep core engaged, body in line
Push back up to start
Dont let shoulders shrug at top
Add scapular protraction (plus) at top

modifications.harder: Full push-up, feet elevated, single leg

exercises.name: Overhead Press
exercises.description: Pressing weights overhead for overall shoulder strength. Fundamental exercise for shoulder function.
instructions: Stand or sit with weights at shoulder height
Palms facing forward
Press weights straight up overhead
Fully extend arms without locking elbows
Lower slowly with control
Keep core engaged
Dont arch lower back
common_mistakes: Pressing forward instead of straight up

modifications.harder: Standing, heavier weight, single arm

exercises.name: Arnold Press
exercises.description: A rotating shoulder press that works all three heads of the deltoid. More complex movement pattern.
instructions: Start with weights at shoulder height, palms facing you
As you press up, rotate palms to face forward
Fully extend arms overhead
Reverse the motion coming down
Finish with palms facing you again
Keep movement smooth and controlled
Dont arch back

modifications.harder: Heavier weight, standing

exercises.name: Upright Row
exercises.description: A vertical pulling motion for shoulders and upper traps. Note: can be impingement-provoking - use caution.
instructions: Hold weights in front of thighs
Pull weights up along body
Lead with elbows, not hands
Stop when elbows reach shoulder height
Lower slowly with control
Keep weights close to body
Maintain upright posture

modifications.harder: Heavier weight

exercises.name: Isometric Shoulder Flexion
exercises.description: Pushing against a wall or door frame without movement to build strength without stressing the joint.
instructions: Stand facing wall, arm at side
Make a fist and press into wall
Push as if trying to raise arm forward
Wall prevents movement (isometric)
Hold contraction for prescribed time
Relax and repeat
Keep rest of body relaxed

modifications.harder: Maximum contraction, longer holds

exercises.name: Isometric Shoulder Abduction
exercises.description: Pushing outward against a wall or door frame for isometric shoulder strengthening.
instructions: Stand next to wall, arm at side
Press outside of wrist into wall
Push as if trying to raise arm sideways
Wall prevents movement
Hold contraction
Relax and repeat
Can also use door frame

modifications.harder: Maximum contraction, arm slightly elevated

exercises.name: Isometric External Rotation
exercises.description: Pressing outward against door frame with elbow bent to strengthen external rotators isometrically.
instructions: Stand in doorway, elbow bent 90 degrees
Elbow at side, forearm against door frame
Press outward against frame
As if trying to rotate forearm out
Hold contraction
Keep elbow pinned to side
Relax and repeat

modifications.harder: Maximum contraction, longer holds

exercises.name: Wall Clock Exercise
exercises.description: Tracing clock positions on wall to improve multi-directional shoulder mobility and control.
instructions: Stand facing wall, arm extended touching wall
Move hand to 12 oclock position (overhead)
Return to center, then move to 3 oclock (side)
Continue to 6 oclock (down) and 9 oclock
Move to intermediate positions as well
Keep arm straight when possible
Move slowly and controlled

modifications.harder: Full range all positions, add ball under hand

exercises.name: Prone Shoulder Extension
exercises.description: Lifting arm backward while lying face down to strengthen posterior shoulder. Part of the prone progression series.
instructions: Lie face down on bench or mat
Arm hanging down, palm facing body
Lift arm straight back toward ceiling
Squeeze shoulder blade
Hold briefly at top
Lower with control
Keep arm straight

modifications.harder: Add light weight, hold at top

exercises.name: Supine Shoulder Flexion
exercises.description: Raising arm overhead while lying on back. Gravity-minimized position for early shoulder strengthening.
instructions: Lie on back with arms at sides
Hold light weight or no weight
Raise arm up and overhead toward floor behind
Keep elbow straight
Go as far as comfortable
Return to starting position
Move slowly with control

modifications.easier: No weight, assisted with other hand
modifications.harder: Add weight, hold at end range

exercises.name: Pectoralis Minor Stretch
exercises.description: A stretch specifically for the pectoralis minor muscle which can contribute to forward shoulder posture.
instructions: Stand in doorway or corner
Place forearms on wall/doorframe above head
Step through with one foot
Lean chest through doorway
Feel stretch in upper chest near shoulder
Keep core engaged
Hold and breathe
common_mistakes: Arms too low (becomes pec major stretch)

modifications.harder: Greater lean, longer holds

exercises.name: Chin Tuck
exercises.description: A postural exercise to correct forward head position which often accompanies shoulder problems.
instructions: Sit or stand with good posture
Look straight ahead
Draw chin straight back (like making a double chin)
Dont tilt head up or down
Feel stretch at base of skull
Hold briefly
Relax and repeat

modifications.easier: Shorter holds, against wall for feedback
modifications.harder: Longer holds, resistance band around head

exercises.name: Seated Thoracic Rotation
exercises.description: Rotational stretch for the thoracic spine. Important because thoracic mobility affects shoulder function.
instructions: Sit upright in chair, feet flat
Cross arms over chest
Rotate trunk to one side
Keep hips facing forward
Look in direction of rotation
Hold at end range
Return to center and rotate other way
common_mistakes: Rotating from hips instead of spine

modifications.harder: Arms overhead, hold longer

exercises.name: Open Book Stretch
exercises.description: A side-lying thoracic rotation stretch that opens the chest and improves spinal mobility for better shoulder function.
instructions: Lie on side with knees bent 90 degrees
Arms stacked in front at shoulder height
Open top arm toward ceiling and behind
Follow hand with eyes
Try to get shoulder to floor behind you
Keep knees stacked and stable
Return and repeat

modifications.harder: Longer holds, straighten top leg

contraindications: Acute low back or rib injury

exercises.name: I-Y-T-W Series
exercises.description: A comprehensive series of prone exercises forming letters with the arms to target all scapular muscles.
instructions: Lie prone on bench or floor
I: Arms overhead, thumbs up, lift arms
Y: Arms at 45 degrees, thumbs up, lift arms
T: Arms at 90 degrees (to sides), thumbs up, lift arms
W: Elbows bent, rotate and lift in W shape
Hold each position briefly
Lower with control

modifications.easier: One letter at a time, no weight
modifications.harder: Add light dumbbells, hold each longer

exercises.name: Full Can Exercise
exercises.description: Raising arm with thumb up (like holding a full can) to target supraspinatus with less impingement than empty can.
instructions: Stand with arm at side, thumb pointing up
Raise arm to 90 degrees in scapular plane
Keep thumb pointing up throughout
Lower with control
Maintain good posture
Avoid shrugging
Can use light weight

modifications.harder: Add light dumbbell, hold at top

exercises.name: External Rotation Wall Slide
exercises.description: Sliding arm up wall while maintaining external rotation. Combines flexion with rotational control.
instructions: Stand next to wall, elbow bent at side
Forearm against wall, palm facing forward
Slide forearm up wall
Maintain external rotation throughout
Go as high as you can keeping forearm on wall
Slide back down with control
Keep shoulder blade down
common_mistakes: Losing external rotation (forearm coming off wall)

modifications.harder: Greater range, pause at top

exercises.name: Bear Hug Stretch
exercises.description: Self-hugging stretch for the rhomboids and mid-back. Opens up the back of the shoulder girdle.
instructions: Wrap arms around yourself like a hug
Grab opposite shoulders or reach further
Round upper back forward
Pull shoulder blades apart
Feel stretch between shoulder blades
Drop chin toward chest
Hold and breathe

modifications.harder: Greater rounding, longer holds

exercises.name: Prone Snow Angel
exercises.description: A prone exercise moving arms through a snow angel pattern to work shoulder mobility and scapular control through full range.
instructions: Lie face down with forehead on mat
Start with arms at sides, palms down
Lift arms slightly off floor
Sweep arms out and up overhead like snow angel
Keep arms lifted throughout
Reverse back to starting position
Move slowly and with control

modifications.easier: Arms can rest briefly between reps
modifications.harder: Hold light weights, pause at overhead

metadata.notes: Tier 1 exercises (cat-camel, cobra-stretch, dead-bug) have full AI form detection. Tier 2 exercises are guided only with video/instructions.
